Title: Hooter's Valentine's Day Special Promises Free Wings for Photos of Your Ex
Byline: A Valentine's Day special at Hooters promises free wings for photos of your ex.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Bill Murray Said 'Religion Is the Worst Enemy of Mankind'
Byline: Rumors that popular comedian Bill Murray proclaimed 'Religion is the worst enemy of mankind' originated with a fake news article.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: 'Be Like Bill' Spreads Malware?
Byline: The "Be Like Bill" Facebook trend has annoyed some social media users, but there are no credible reports of its behaving maliciously.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Only Women Showed up to the U.S. Senate After a Snowstorm?
Byline: After a major snowstorm, two female lawmakers held a brief administrative session to postpone Senate business.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: (Nearly) Frozen Waves
Byline: A series of photographs shows nearly (but not completely) frozen waves off the coast of Nantucket.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Does the Nagapushpa Flower Bloom Every 36 Years?
Byline: A photograph purportedly showing a rare blooming "Nagapushpa flower" actually depicts a type of marine invertebrate known as a sea pen.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: FALSE: Trump Tweets Image of Bernie Sanders in Gas Chamber
Byline: A social media game of telephone led to the mistaken belief Donald Trump tweeted an image of himself sending Bernie Sanders to a gas chamber.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: FALSE: Trump Supporters Misspelled His Name with Shirts
Byline: A photograph showing Trump supporters spelling out "T-R-M-U-P" on their shirts is fake.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: MISCAPTIONED: JetBlue Plane Buried by Snow
Byline: A photograph that purportedly shows a JetBlue airliner buried in snow is actually the product of a tricky camera angle.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: FALSE: Photograph Shows Amy Winehouse with Lana Del Rey
Byline: A photograph showing Amy Winehouse and Lana Del Rey together is a composite of two separate images.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Was George Zimmerman Found Dead After Posting Pics of Trayvon Martin's Body?
Byline: Junk news strikes again.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: 'Pretty Woman' Sequel a Hoax
Byline: Richard Gere is not connected to a Facebook fan page that promises a "Pretty Woman" sequel is in the works if it receives an appropriate number of "likes."
Author: Dan Evon

Title: MISCAPTIONED: Baby Elephant Talk
Byline: The playful baby elephant seen in a touching photograph was zoo-born; he didn't lose his mother to poachers.
Author: David Mikkelson

Title: 'Gates of Heaven' Photograph
Byline: A manipulated photograph of the Swan Nebula was passed around as an image of "The Gates of Heaven" that has supposedly befuddled astronomers.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Did a Teenaged Customer Argue with a Muslim Cashier Over His Cross Necklace?
Byline: A viral story related a cross-related confrontation involving a 17-year-old boy in St. Cloud, Minnesota.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Bernie Sanders Marched with MLK at Selma?
Byline: A photograph doesn't show Bernie Sanders marching from Selma to Montgomery in 1965 with Martin Luther King, Jr.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Did Abraham Lincoln Meet Edgar Allan Poe?
Byline: A photograph showing Abraham Lincoln with author Edgar Allan Poe imagines a fascinating rendezvous.
Author: David Mikkelson

Title: Super Moon, Perfectly Timed
Byline: Take a closer look at this ethereal photograph showing a "super moon" perched atop a radio telescope.
Author: David Mikkelson

Title: Does a Red Fox Scream When It Finds Its Soulmate?
Byline: A Tumblr meme suggested that the red fox screams when it locates its perfect mate.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: IRS Scam Season
Byline: Tax season in 2016 triggered a number of novel riffs on common Internal Revenue Service-based scams.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Utility Pole Buried in Snow
Byline: A photograph shows a utility pole that has been buried in snow, but the amount of snow is a matter of dispute.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: MISCAPTIONED: Arnold Schwarzenegger's First Day in NYC
Byline: A photograph purportedly showing Arnold Schwarzenegger's first day in New York is actually a still from his first film.
Author: Dan Evon

Byline: A photograph purportedly showing U.S. students praying at a mosque as part of the Common Core curriculum was actually taken in the Netherlands.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Is This the Vatican Women's Rifle Team?
Byline: "The Vatican decided that Nuns with Guns was not a good image for the Catholic Church ..."
Author: Dan Evon

Byline: A popular photograph purportedly showing a hapless 'Who Wants to Be a Millionaire' contestant is actually from a sketch comedy show.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Height of the Texas Giants
Byline: A photograph shows four Texas brothers who were all said to be nearly 8 feet tall, but their actual heights are still debated.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: MISCAPTIONED: Snowfall in Saudi Arabia
Byline: Saudi Arabia experienced heavy snowfall in January 2016, but this photograph of snow-covered palm trees wasn't taken there.
Author: David Mikkelson

Title: John and Lisa Robinson Powerball Giveaway Hoax
Byline: A new Facebook hoax claims that Powerball winners John and Lisa Robinson are giving away their money on Facebook.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Did Hillary Clinton Wear Blackface at a Costume Party?
Byline: A photograph showing a woman in blackface and a man dressed as a hillbilly is not a picture of Bill and Hillary Clinton.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Joint Chiefs of Staff Flip Obama Off During SOTU?
Byline: No, this photo doesn't depict the Joint Chiefs of Staff giving President Obama the finger during the State of the Union address.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: The Lying Game
Byline: Numerous people on social media are falsely claiming that they won the $1.6 Powerball lottery jackpot.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Photo Does Not Show Baby Great White Shark
Byline: A photograph showing a "baby great white shark" actually shows a salmon shark.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Alan Rickman Rocking Chair Meme
Byline: A quote falsely attributed to Alan Rickman about the Harry Potter series became popular on social media after his death.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Is This a Real Photograph of Bowie and Lemmy?
Byline: The photo began circulating soon after both musicians passed away.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Obama Did Not Wear Shutter Shades After 2016 SOTU
Byline: A photograph showing President Obama wearing American flag glasses was not taken after the 2016 State of the Union address.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Does a Photograph Show Pigs Forced Into Tiny Cages?
Byline: An outrage-provoking photograph showing pigs confined in confiningly small cages is real, but the accompanying description of it is inaccurate.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Donald Trump Compared Prep School to Military Service?
Byline: Donald Trump did compare prep school to military service, but this viral quote isn't completely accurate.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Does a Photograph Show a Frozen Spider Web?
Byline: A photograph purportedly depicting a "frozen spider web" is actually a picture of an ice sculpture.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Does a Billboard in Finland Promote Rape by Refugees?
Byline: A photograph purportedly showing a billboard in Finland that condones rape is fake.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Powerball Wealth Sharing Meme
Byline: If a $1.3 billion Powerball jackpot were shared with every American, we'd all get about four bucks each.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: FALSE: CNN Host Fareed Zakaria calls for Jihad Rape of White Women
Byline: Fake news reports that CNN host Fareed Zakaria posted a blog entry calling for white women to be raped by Islamic minority groups.
Author: Snopes Staff

Title: Delaware Child Support Card
Byline: A fake news story about a new Delaware "Child Support Card" hit the online world in January 2016.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: FALSE: Bill Clinton Told Tony Blair He Likes to Punch Slabs of Ham
Byline: A comedian created a fake transcript of a conversation between Tony Blair and Bill Clinton.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Obama Crying Like a Psychopath Meme
Byline: Body language expert Lillian Glass said a popular meme misconstrued one of her quotes and made assertions that aren't credible or ethical.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: FALSE: Submarine Abandoned in Desert
Byline: A photograph showing an abandoned submarine in a desert is a composite of two images.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Donald Trump Browser Filter
Byline: A Chrome browser extension can remove all mention of Donald Trump from a user's online experience.
Author: Brooke Binkowski

Title: FALSE: Ammon Bundy Compared Himself To Rosa Parks
Byline: A Twitter user claiming to be Ammon Bundy posted a message comparing the takeover of a government building in Oregon with the civil rights movement.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Did Officers in Georgia Kill Over 250 People?
Byline: The humor in a parody post on Facebook was lost on many who don't watch a popular zombie-themed television series.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Wendy's $1 'Free Frosty' Key Tag?
Byline: There were more questions than answers on social media about Wendy's $1 Frosty Key Tag promotion.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Connecticut Begins Sending Gun Confiscation Letters
Byline: Social media users rediscovered a March 2014 article claiming Connecticut residents received "gun confiscation letters" and mistook its claims as current or accurate.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Chevy Chase Death Hoax
Byline: Actor/comedian Chevy Chase did not die of a heart attack in January 2016.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Six Flags Roller Coaster Flooding
Byline: A photograph of a roller coaster submerged by floodwaters was not taken in St. Louis in 2017.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Did Archaeologists Dig Up an 800-Year-Old Alien Cellphone?
Byline: A picture of an ancient cellphone supposedly unearthed by archaeologists was just a photograph of a modern replica.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Fake Clint Eastwood Quote
Byline: A fake quote attributed to Clint Eastwod started circulating around the internet in November 2015.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Was Bill Cosby's Hollywood Walk of Fame Star Removed?
Byline: A photograph of maintenance on Bill Cosby's Hollywood 'Walk of Fame' star led to rumors that the plaque was to be removed.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Did the U.S. Remove 'Country of Origin' Labeling from Meat?
Byline: A meme about the purported removal of "country of origin" labeling on meat contained a mixture of true and false information.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Did a Shark Attack on a Missouri Highway?
Byline: A creative photograph depicting a shark attacking a motorist on a Missouri highway went viral in December 2015.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Does This Photograph Show a Dog Burned While Rescuing Its Family?
Byline: What happens when a social media prank achieves its intended results.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Deleted Tamir Rice Photo
Byline: A circulating photograph of a young man holding what appeared to be two guns did not depict Tamir Rice.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Is This Man Surfing with a Whale?
Byline: Photobombing is seemingly an activity not limited to terrestrial mammals.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Muslims Stealing Propane at Home Depot?
Byline: A photograph of indeterminate origin doesn't depict Muslims "buying or stealing" propane tanks in Miami.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Obama Begins Confiscating Guns by Force
Byline: A vague, viral blog post claimed that President Obama had begun "confiscating guns by force," then went on to describe nothing of the sort.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Facebook Cold Stone Pregnancy Discount
Byline: By and large, Cold Stone Creamery isn't giving away free or discounted ice cream to women who appear to be pregnant.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: JC Penney Fairview Heights Flag Controversy
Byline: A Facebook user claimed the JC Penney Portrait Studio in Fairview Heights, Illinois refused to take a photo with an American flag because it "went against their belief."
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Ted Cruz Doesn't Want to 'Netflix and Chill' with You
Byline: A fake promotion to "Netflix and Chill" with Ted Cruz has been circulated via Twitter.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Gas Station Shuns Serviceman?
Byline: A Facebook user claimed that a Long Island gas station refused to sell his son tobacco chew because the store doesn't serve the military.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: A Fake Tweet from Donald Trump
Byline: A viral anti-immigration tweet purportedly issued by Donald Trump is a fake.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Are These Donald Trump's Sons in Game-Hunting Photos?
Byline: Photographs show Donald Trump Jr. and Eric Trump posing with kills from a 2012 big game hunting trip
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Do the Oldest and Weakest Wolves Really Lead the Pack?
Byline: A photograph of a wolf pack is commonly shared with an inaccurate description of the behavior of wolves.
Author: Dan Evon

Byline: A deceptive photograph seemingly shows a man perilously hanging from the edge of a high cliff.  He's actually in no danger at all.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Donald Trump Doesn't Salute the Flag?
Byline: An image of Donald Trump not placing his hand over his heart during the playing of the U.S. national anthem doesn't reflect reality.

Title: Tommy Chong Death Hoax
Byline: A death hoax about comedian Tommy Chong has been republished several times, but the Cheech and Chong partner is still alive.

Byline: Newt Gingrich almost certainly wasn't referencing the San Bernardino shooting in a 13 November 2015 tweet.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: New Punishment for Reading the Bible in Saudi Arabia?
Byline: A gruesome photograph of a shredded hand doesn't depict a "new punishment for reading the Bible" in Saudi Arabia.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: IKEA Is Selling a Swastika-Shaped Table
Byline: A photograph of a swastika-shaped table actually captures the work a Berlin-based artist and not an actual IKEA furniture product.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Ferrero Rocher Chocolates Filled with Maggots?
Byline: Viral videos showing Ferrero Rocher chocolates crawling with insects are real but not evidence of a manufacturing problem.

Title: Chemtrails Switch Photo
Byline: A photograph of a chemtrails switch is fake.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Charlie Brown Christmas 'Christian Content' Warnings
Byline: No, the Charlie Brown Christmas special didn't air with "Christian content warnings."
Author: Kim LaCapria

Byline: Popular memes assert that former heavyweight champion Jack Johnson invented the monkey wrench, and that it was so named as a racial slur.
Author: Dan Evon

Byline: The social media outrage machine went into overdrive following claims a Brooklyn principal banned holidays and the Pledge of Allegiance.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Death of Rachel Hoffman
Byline: A popular meme claims 23-year-old Rachel Hoffman was murdered by drug dealers after she was pressured to turn informant over a small possession charge.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Byline: Social media rumors claim several suspicious purchases of 60 cell phones were made by Middle Eastern men at Walmarts in or around Lebanon, Missouri.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Byline: A Facebook post asserted that the British government banned the Lord's Prayer in cinemas, but then allowed Islamic messages to be displayed on London buses.

Byline: Rumors claimed lawyers for Tashfeen Malik (and an MSNBC host) discouraged publishing images of her face because doing so was offensive to Muslims.

Title: Is Safyre Terry's Christmas Wish a Scam?
Byline: A request to send Christmas cards to 8-year-old Safyre Terry is not a scam.

Byline: President Obama was not photographed holding a rocket launcher in a car with ISIS leader Abu Bakr Al-Baghdadi.

Byline: Donald Trump made some confusing remarks about an internet shutdown or ban, but he appeared to be describing a counterterror plan.

Byline: A widely circulated image does not depict a "pro-ISIS rally" held in Dearborn, Michigan, but rather an anti-ISIS demonstration.

Byline: Be wary of memes with unsourced mug shots.
Author: Dan Evon

Byline: A meme claimed Frederick Trump was a pimp and drug dealer who made his fortune running a brothel and opium den.

Byline: A photograph of a child standing in a litter container next to a sign that reads "Dispose of Your Ugly Children Here" is fake.

Byline: A customer on the company's Facebook page expressed her views on same-sex unions.

Byline: Nationalists marched on Poland's independence day (11 November 2015), but the demonstrations weren't ignored by news media in Europe.

Byline: A photograph showing a protester holding a sign reading "Lincoln Was Racist" is fake.
Author: Dan Evon

Byline: A shocking image was circulated with a warning to pet owners to check their dogs' mouths for beetles.

Byline: A vintage Superman poster shows the comic book hero talking to children about the importance of respecting diversity.

Byline: A viral quote describing various tragedies in the life of Keanu Reeves was not penned by the actor.

Title: Does This Photo Show a Syrian Child 'Surrendering' to a Camera?
Byline: Hands up or I'll photograph.
Author: Dan Evon

Byline: A video of Syrian refugees purportedly complaining about a lack of TVs and slow Internet service has been taken far out of context.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Byline: Contrary to a popular meme, Japan has not "kept Islam at bay" by enforcing strict laws on Muslims.

Byline: Religious-themed Christmas stamps are still available for purchase from the United States Postal Service.

Byline: Here's the truth behind an old photograph purportedly showing a man holding a massive bullfrog.
Author: Dan Evon

Byline: A tweet published by The Onion led many social media users to believe orcas were held in plastic bags while their habitats were cleaned.

Byline: A Hunter's Moon doesn't create the illusion of two suns, isn't a miracle, and occurs annually.

Byline: A UFO supposedly photographed over Memphis, Tennessee, by several different people was actually sci-fi fan art.

Byline: Memes assert Ben Carson benefited from welfare early in life, only to say such programs caused the "disintegration of the family unit" and "enslav[ed] African-Americans."

Byline: A digitally manipulated photograph purportedly shows that the In-N-Out Burger chain printed "Hail Satan" on their beverage cups.
Author: Dan Evon

Byline: Popular NASA photographs purportedly highlighting the dramatic effects of deforestation in North America actually show the Earth in different seasons.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Dueling Memes Debate Denmark's Social Infrastructure
Byline: Contrasting memes describe the benefits and downside of living within the Danish social system.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Freshwater Snark
Byline: This photograph shows a real shark, but not on the shores of Michigan.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Are Johnny Bravo and Powerpuff Girls Films on the Way?
Byline: Fake movie posters depict Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson as Johnny Bravo and Emma Watson, Emma Stone, and Ellen Page as The Powerpuff Girls.
Author: Dan Evon

Byline: A viral story about a floating city in China suspiciously lacked more proof than a single grainy video or photograph.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Are These Photographs of a Young Betty White?
Byline: "Betty's classic beauty put her on over 300 magazine covers and books."
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Mr. Peebles
Byline: Mr. Peebles might be the world's smallest Photoshopped cat, but he doesn't exist in the physical world.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Did Facebook Rule That Military Emblems Are Not Appropriate?
Byline: A Facebook-posted meme claimed that Facebook does not consider military emblems appropriate content for their social network.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Does the U.S. Have the Third-Highest Rate of Homicides Worldwide?
Byline: A meme asserts that the U.S. has the third-highest rate of homicides worldwide but drops dramatically in the rankings if four major cities are excluded from the stats.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Did a Drunken Sailor Use a Raccoon to Bypass an Ignition Interlock?
Byline: A humorous viral police report claimed a drunk Navy petty officer used a raccoon to bypass an ignition interlock system installed in his vehicle.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Does a Photograph Show Planned Parenthood's Founder at a KKK Rally?
Byline: Margaret Sanger once addressed female KKK members in a bid to have her message heard as widely as possible, but she disparaged the group's mission.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Did This Woman Confuse Spray Foam Insulation for Mousse?
Byline: A photograph supposedly shows a woman who mistakenly used expanding foam insulation on her hair instead of hair mousse.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Byline: Some fantasy Happy Meal artwork from 2014 was presented on Facebook the following year as representing a real McDonald's offering.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Byline: Images from the 'The Simpsons' showing Donald Trump's announcement of his presidential candidacy are from 2015, not 2000.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Does a Photograph Show Obama Wearing an Aleister Crowley T-Shirt?
Byline: 'Twas magic that put Aleister Crowley's face on President Barack Obama's t-shirt. Digital magic, I say!
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Zoinksberg
Byline: Can Facebook users check if their accounts have been hacked by commenting "@[4.0]" on posts?
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Did  President Obama Pose Next to a Mile 69 or 420 Marker?
Byline: Images showing President Obama next to signs displaying the numbers "69" or "420" are digitally edited creations.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Mexico-Guatemala Border Wall
Byline: Multiple photographs purporting to show a border wall between Mexico and Guatemala actually picture barriers in other parts of the world.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Meijer $75 Coupon Scam
Byline: The Meijer supercenter chain is not giving away $75 coupons to users who like and share Facebook posts; it's a form of survey scam.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Did These Boys Disappear After Discovering a Treasure Map?
Byline: A picture of them was supposedly slipped under their parents' front door one year later.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Do Huggies Wipes Contain Glass Shards?
Byline: Viral claims maintained that some lots of Huggies brand baby wipes are impregnated with tiny shards of glass.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Does This Photograph Show a Suspension Bridge Warning Sign?
Byline: A sign in Costa Rica warn supposedly warns hikers that a suspension bridge can hold ten people but only three Americans.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Is This a Poster for a New 'Twilight' Movie?
Byline: A poster advertising a forthcoming "Twilight" film was simply a fan tribute.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Empire Goddess
Byline: Was an image of the Hindu goddess Kali projected onto the Empire State Building?
Author: Dan Evon

Title: How to Vote in Mexico
Byline: Mexican citizens are indeed required to have government-issued photo ID cards in order to vote in federal elections.
Author: David Mikkelson

Title: Did Joe Biden Misremember Who Attacked Pearl Harbor?
Byline: Don't believe everything you see in a meme, even supposed quotes from gaffe-prone politicians.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Is the Owner of Jimmy John's a Big-Game Hunter?
Byline: Photographs show Jimmy John Liautaud, the owner of Jimmy John's Gourmet Sandwiches, with animal kills from big game hunts.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: The Great Pacific Garbage Patch
Byline: A shocking photograph shows ocean debris directly resulting from the massive 2011 earthquake in Japan, not specifically the 'Great Pacific Garbage Patch.'
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Did Facebook Ban the Posting of U.S. Marine Corps Emblems?
Byline: A Facebook page was reportedly suspended because its U.S. Marine Corps emblem was deemed to violate the network's community standards
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Fallen Angel
Byline: Do photographs show a real-life fallen angel that was captured after it dropped from the skies?
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Do You Need a Driver's License to Legally Operate a Car on Public Roads?
Byline: Despite what you may read on social media, you still need a driver's license to legally drive a car, and the U.S. Supreme Court hasn't ruled otherwise.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Are Mutated Daisies Growing Near Fukushima?
Byline: A photograph purportedly shows mutated Shasta daisies growing near the Fukushima nuclear power plant in Japan.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Does a Video Show the Effects of Drinking 24 Cans of Red Bull?
Byline: A viral video captures a patient suffering from blunt force trauma flail chest, not from the deleterious effects of consuming two dozen cans of Red Bull energy drink.
Author: David Mikkelson

Title: Abandoned Polish Wedding Chairs
Byline: An intriguing image of chairs with trees growing through reportedly stems from an ill-fated wedding in Poland that was halted by the onset of World War II.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Hillary Clinton's Confederacy Background
Byline: A photograph showing a young Hillary Clinton posing with a Confederate flag visible in the background is a digital fabrication.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Is This a Photograph of Wounded Female Veterans?
Byline: A photograph of women with missing limbs is actually a picture of Brazilian amputees, not wounded veterans.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Pizza Vending Machines
Byline: Rumors of the imminent arrival of pizza vending machines swept social media in mid-2015, but those machines have been "coming soon" for several years now.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Do These Photographs Show Gary Dourdan 'Before and After'?
Byline: A "now and then" photograph set supposedly shows 'CSI' actor Gary Dourdan before and after heavy drug use.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Is Facebook Banning Users Who Post Photos of Confederate Flags?
Byline: Social media networks did not announce they would be banning users who post images of the Confederate flag.
Author: David Mikkelson

Title: Is This a Real Obama Campaign Button?
Byline: The pictured button was not an official 2012 presidential campaign pin.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: A (Not So) Secret Microchip?
Byline: Is Samsung stealing data and photographs from cell phone users via a secret chip implanted in their batteries?
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Did a Couple Kill a Dolphin by Urinating on It?
Byline: Claims that photographs depict a couple who killed a dolphin by urinating in its blowhole were inaccurate, although it's true that handling dolphins can kill them.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Was the World's Largest Snake Captured in the Amazon?
Byline: Fake news and fake photographs supposedly document the capture of a 134-foot-long anaconda caught after it had eaten 257 people and 2325 animals.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: One of These Dogs Is Not Like the Otters
Byline: We're not sure who looks more surprised in this photograph.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Is This 'Gatorboarding' Photo Real?
Byline: A viral photograph purportedly captured a raccoon riding an alligator like a surfboard.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Heaven's Trail Viral Photo
Byline: A famous photograph commonly referred to as "Heaven's Trail" wasn't taken in Ireland and does not depict a biennial astronomical event.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Summer Job Interview or Human Trafficking Front?
Byline: Companies advertising summer jobs for young adults have been falsely tagged in social media as fronts for human trafficking.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Hillary Clinton Meets Osama bin Laden
Byline: A photograph of Hillary Clinton shaking hands with Osama bin Laden is a fabrication created for a Photoshop contest.
Author: David Mikkelson

Title: Spam Oreos? Another Fake Flavor Goes Viral
Byline: Spam joins the list of rumored Oreo flavors (bacon cream, fried chicken, cheeseburger) not actually being produced by Nabisco.
Author: Dan Evon

Title: Is Breast Milk Gold Under a Microscope?
Byline: An intriguing image of breast milk under high magnification shows it to be glittery gold in appearance.
Author: Kim LaCapria

Title: Marilyn Monroe Funeral Photograph
Byline: An image showing a deceased Marilyn Monroe in her funeral casket is an artistic recreation, not a real photograph of the event.
Author: Dan Evon
